title: Packet loss: ISP or home network?
body:
So I've been dealing with random packet loss throughout games since I moved and got internet through Consolidated Communications which is a fiber connection (formerly SureWest, I'll refer to them as CC from here), which leads me to believe this is a problem on CC's end as I'm using the same router that had no issues before with Comcast internet. 

I've gone through the whole gamut of options for testing and optimizing my own network, running tracert, pinging the NA server and testing my connection using not only Riot's recommended site on their support page, but other stand alone sites as well, changing my DNS servers, using port forwarding/triggering and nothing has worked. Tests have shown no problems with my connection, and even in game I maintain a constant 65-70ms, without ping spikes (just the packet loss that randomly occurs). When pinging the server through cmd prompt, I see consistent times to the server (60-70ms), but do see a few packets that get lost, with the most recent test only losing 2 out of 757 packets sent. I'm using a TP-Link Archer C9 router, and yes I'm hard wired to the router. I've put in tickets with Riot and received no response, as well as calling CC, but they say they see no issues with my connection and do not have any ports or connections blocked in any way. Does anyone have any experience with CC or what I'm experiencing, or have suggestions on what more I can try to rid myself of this problem?

TL;DR - Experiencing packet loss using Consolidated Communications ISP, ruining games, need help.

replies.body:
hi guys. so ive been running into the same issue but mines significantly worse. im also running on a wireless connection but same symptoms. ive ran cmd to ping my home network, google, and other services that all come back with 0 packet loss and a steady connection. but when i ping pvp.net i cannot connect. in game its perfect for about a minute before i start disconnecting, or a custom game will be fine but then i try a pvp game and disconnect as soon as im needed (never am i ever lucky). i ran the diagnostic tool posted earlier and these were my results:

|dynamic-acs-24-101-53-1.zoominternet.net -    0 |   86 |   86 |    8 |   56 |  993 |   17 |
|static-acs-24-129-240-213.zoominternet.net -    0 |   86 |   86 |    9 |   52 |  988 |   10 |
|                   No response from host -  100 |   17 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |
|                   No response from host -  100 |   17 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |
|                   No response from host -  100 |   17 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |
|                   No response from host -  100 |   17 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |    0 |

|          ae35-br01.chi01.riotdirect.net -    0 |   86 |   86 |   68 |  119 | 1060 |   77 |

I know this is pretty late but I have the same thing with CC as you except it's massive packet loss.

It definitely sounds like you've taken a good list of logical steps to troubleshoot this on your own. In my experience, reaching out to an ISP for help can become difficult without providing them certain context on the issue. In this case, I'd recommend running a proper traceroute log using a program called [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/). After loading up the app, pop **104.160.131.1** into the host field and then start the trace. After the trace has run for about 5 minutes or longer, export the results as text and paste them in a reply to me.

I believe this log will reveal any routing issues you may be having and will be a great asset in getting this resolved for good. Let me know if you ran into any issues!

Thanks for the quick response, I tried providing as much information as I could to the ISP, and even had one of their US based techs try to work out the issue with me, but to no avail. 

I've run the trace using WinMTR on 104.160.131.1, posted results below as imgur link and text, the text just isn't really formatting correctly so thought a screenshot might be easier to read. The test ran for ~10 min. or so.

http://imgur.com/a/xcZpn


|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

|                                      WinMTR statistics                                   |

|                       Host              -   %  | Sent | Recv | Best | Avrg | Wrst | Last |

|------------------------------------------------|------|------|------|------|------|------|

|                             192.168.1.1 -    0 |  573 |  573 |    0 |    0 |    1 |    0 |

|    001.148-78-65.ftth.swbr.surewest.net -    0 |  573 |  573 |    0 |    1 |   23 |    0 |

|                             172.22.5.81 -    1 |  569 |  568 |    0 |    0 |   29 |    0 |

|                             172.21.2.13 -    0 |  573 |  573 |    1 |    1 |   17 |    1 |

|     117.98-30-64.ftth.swbr.surewest.net -    0 |  573 |  573 |    1 |    1 |   18 |    1 |

|                  sjo-b21-link.telia.net -    1 |  569 |  568 |    5 |    5 |   28 |    7 |

   WinMTR v0.92 GPL V2 by Appnor MSP - Fully Managed Hosting & Cloud Provider

Hey, thanks for that trace! It looks like your network path is pretty normal, aside from the consistent 1% packet loss through most of your route. Such a low amount of packet loss shouldn't cause issues, though. I'd recommend hopping into some custom matches so you can verify that you're experiencing the symptoms of your packet loss before running another traceroute during a period of time when these symptoms show up. I believe this will capture the data we need to figure out what's going on.

Interesting, I can say that the issue occurs every game at all times of the day, and occurs in the same exact way (meaning just a small moment of lost data, i.e. minions stop for a second then appear elsewhere, etc.) on multiple PCs on the network, all of which are hardwired. It's random enough to simply play through it, but when it happens during a team fight or while trying to CS it is pretty unfortunate for us. 

I can try running a trace for a longer period of time, or even recording during a game to capture a moment when the packet loss happens to confirm that's actually what is going on.
Yeah, running a trace while playing a match where you're seeing the symptoms may be the best way for us to capture what's going on in the backend.

Here is the WinMTR trace I ran while playing a game. I experienced the packet loss a couple times through the game, but still only see a 1% loss across the hosts.

http://imgur.com/a/Lg3f7

While we didn't capture huge bursts of packet loss, what we did capture was consistent packet loss once again, along with a few different spikes in your latency before reaching our servers. The **172.22.5.81 and sjo-b21-link.telia.net** nodes specifically encountered issues and could be the source of the issues you're experiencing. I believe this traceroute has enough data to provide your ISP's tier 2 technicians so they can look into this further with you.

I hope this helped!

I called my ISP, eventually got a tech that started running tracrts to your server and claimed anything that is happening is outside of their server, and wouldn't even take the data I have from the WinMTR trace showing loss within their network. Am I just out of luck here then? I may try again to get a different tech, the first one seemed to just write me off as quick as he could.

edit: after thinking about how the tech wanted me to directly connect to the line and he couldn't see my computer, I took a look at the cable coming from the box and noticed it was old and wired strangely. Ran a new line from the box to the inside of the house and haven't seen an issue since. :)

Holy nuggets! That's awesome that you were able to run a new line and resolve this on your own. Nice work!

{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}
Cool I'll try that tonight, lost power for a few days here after a storm. I'll post the log once I run the trace, thanks.
